title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with technical, media, communications, or marketing background will be assigned to the office. Additionally, individuals will be appointed within various components and offices of the Department to support the efforts. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary responsible for coordinating activities to counter violent extremism across all department components. Responsibilities include identifying risk factors, populations targeted by extremist propaganda, and managing outreach and engagement. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is responsible for identifying populations targeted by extremist propaganda, managing outreach activities, ensuring relevant information informs counter-extremism efforts, and developing a department-wide strategy to counter violent extremism. This includes a focus on a counter-messaging program using various technologies and social media platforms. The Department of Homeland Security's Office for Countering Violent Extremism is tasked with developing a strategy to counter violent extremism, including leveraging technology and social media for counter-messaging. This involves engaging with various partners and ensuring activities respect the principles of countering violent extremism. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism is responsible for developing metrics to evaluate programs, recommending research requirements, and disseminating information to practitioners and partners. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates with various partners to utilize research on extremist propaganda dissemination methods, establish a counter-messaging program, and represent the Department in coordinating activities with other entities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism is responsible for coordinating activities with other federal departments and agencies, representing the Department in international extremism issues, providing guidance on grant usage, and administering grant programs in coordination with FEMA. A memorandum of understanding is required with the Administrator of FEMA. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will establish a grant program in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to assist community groups in creating counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. A memorandum of understanding is required between the Assistant Secretary and the Administrator of FEMA. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program targeting violent extremism. Community groups ineligible for grants are those funding violent extremist activities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress on the Office for Countering Violent Extremism for the next five fiscal years. The report will include a description of the Department's programs and policies, budget, and number of employees dedicated to countering violent extremism programs. The annual report to Congress on the Office for Countering Violent Extremism will include details on the budget, number of full-time and part-time employees dedicated to countering violent extremism programs, activities to cooperate with other departments and agencies, outcome-based metrics for program evaluation, outreach organizations, grants awarded, and training initiatives. The Department conducted outreach, awarded grants, and provided training to counter violent extremism. The annual report will include details on personnel, funding levels, adaptation to threat environment, protection of civil rights, evaluation of grant program effectiveness, and incorporation of lessons learned from other entities. In this section, the term 'violent extremism' is defined as ideologically motivated terrorist activities. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 allocated for the grant program. The section will terminate five years after enactment. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism is authorized $10,000,000 annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 for the grant program.
